title: 112_s1650
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dodd-Frank Improvement Act of 2011" and includes improvements regarding the regulation of derivatives. The "Dodd-Frank Improvement Act of 2011" establishes the Office of Derivatives within the Securities Exchange Commission to oversee security-based swaps, coordinate with other regulators, and recommend new rules for the market. The Office of Derivatives within the Securities Exchange Commission oversees security-based swaps, coordinates with regulators, and monitors market developments. The Director of the Office reports to the Directors of Trading and Risk, Strategy, and Financial Innovation. Staffing includes individuals with expertise in swaps and security-based swaps. The Directors of various divisions will transfer employees to the Office of Derivatives to meet requirements. The Division of Enforcement must consult with the Office before recommending security-based swaps to the Commission. The Office of Derivatives has the right to participate in inspections of certain entities. The Director must submit an annual report on the Office's activities. Additionally, there will be a review of regulatory authority related to derivatives provisions. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to change the term "360" to "720" in certain subsections and introduces an orderly implementation schedule to be adopted by regulatory agencies by December 31, 2011. The final rules required by the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act must be adopted before any other required rules, set forth effective dates, consider economic growth and job creation effects, and address international competitiveness of US financial activities. The curr_chunk discusses the impact of various regulatory requirements on market depth and liquidity, as well as the implications of lack of harmonization among regulatory bodies. The curr_chunk discusses the authority of regulatory bodies to exempt certain entities or transactions from regulatory provisions for the orderly implementation of derivatives regulatory reform. The curr_chunk amends Title VII of the Dodd-Frank Act regarding effective dates and clarifies end user status for swaps. Regulatory bodies have the authority to exempt entities or transactions for the orderly implementation of derivatives regulatory reform. The curr_chunk amends margin requirements for swaps under the Commodity Exchange Act, exempting certain counterparties from these requirements. The curr_chunk exempts certain counterparties from margin requirements for swaps under the Commodity Exchange Act, including entities not primarily invested in physical assets or regulated entities defined in specific acts. The curr_chunk amends rules related to margin requirements for swaps under the Commodity Exchange Act, exempting swaps entered into before final rules become effective. It also revises the definition of a major swap participant to include entities with substantial uncollateralized exposure that could impact financial stability. The curr_chunk discusses the effective date of the amendments made to margin requirements for security-based swaps under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. It clarifies that margin requirements do not apply to security-based swaps where one counterparty is not subject to the regulations. The curr_chunk outlines the criteria for a security-based swap counterparty exempt from margin requirements, including entities such as investment funds, regulated entities, and commodity pools. The curr_chunk discusses exemptions from margin requirements for security-based swaps, including commodity pools predominantly invested in commodities. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act related to uncollateralized counterparty exposure and affiliate transactions. The effective date for these amendments aligns with section 774 of the Act. The curr_chunk discusses the treatment of affiliate transactions under SEC. 713A. The curr_chunk exempts affiliate transactions from being classified as swaps or security-based swaps under the Act. Such transactions must be reported to a swap data repository or the Commission. Additionally, there is a provision for studying international swap regulation under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. The curr_chunk amends the Protection Act by increasing the timeframe for implementation from 18 to 30 days. It also includes an analysis of the progress of countries towards implementing derivatives regulatory reform and its potential effects on the United States. The curr_chunk introduces amendments to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, focusing on the effects on United States competitiveness, market liquidity, and financial stability. The curr_chunk introduces amendments to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, focusing on applicability. The curr_chunk introduces exemptions for activities conducted outside the United States from certain provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act, subject to rules set by regulatory bodies. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission may issue rules to prohibit transactions conducted outside the US that lack a valid business purpose, evade regulatory requirements, or pose a risk to the US financial system. This exemption does not apply to fraud or manipulation provisions.
